items.text: When I walk into a room, I naturally take charge of the situation.
items.rationale: Directly reflects a tendency to assume leadership and dominance in social settings.

items.text: I have no problem telling people exactly what I think, even if it's uncomfortable.
items.rationale: Captures directness and willingness to express opinions forcefully, a hallmark of narcissistic assertiveness.

items.text: People often describe me as someone who speaks with conviction and confidence.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of assertive communication style.

items.text: I don't wait for others to make decisions—I step up and decide.
items.rationale: Behavioral description of proactive decision-making linked to assertive narcissism.

items.text: If someone tries to push me around, I push back harder.
items.rationale: Reflects dominance-oriented assertiveness and refusal to be subordinated.

items.text: I'm the kind of person who sets the agenda in group discussions.
items.rationale: Captures social dominance and initiative-taking in group contexts.

items.text: I rarely back down from a confrontation.
items.rationale: Reflects persistence in conflict situations driven by assertive self-confidence.

items.text: I feel most comfortable when I'm the one calling the shots.
items.rationale: Preference for control and leadership directly maps to assertiveness.

items.text: Others tend to follow my lead because I project certainty.
items.rationale: Third-person framing of assertive influence over others.

items.text: I'm not afraid to voice a dissenting opinion in front of a large group.
items.rationale: Willingness to stand out and oppose consensus reflects assertive self-assurance.

items.text: I can be forceful when I need to get my point across.
items.rationale: Describes forceful communication style characteristic of assertive narcissism.

items.text: I've been told I have a commanding presence.
items.rationale: External feedback about dominance and social impact maps to assertiveness.

items.text: I tend to dominate conversations without always realizing it.
items.rationale: Conversational dominance is assertive, but the lack of awareness could also reflect exhibitionism or entitlement.

items.text: People sometimes say I come across as intimidating, but I see it as being direct.
items.rationale: Captures assertiveness but the interpersonal impact could also relate to devaluing others' comfort.

items.text: I believe people respect me because I demand it through my actions.
items.rationale: Demanding respect through behavior is assertive, but the expectation of respect could map to Authority.

items.text: I am a natural-born leader and people should recognize that.
items.rationale: Directly captures the belief in one's inherent right to lead, central to the Authority facet.

items.text: I have a talent for influencing people and getting them to see things my way.
items.rationale: Reflects perceived superiority in social influence, a core component of narcissistic authority.

items.text: I think I would make an excellent leader for almost any group.
items.rationale: Grandiose self-assessment of leadership ability directly maps to authority.

items.text: People naturally look to me for guidance and direction.
items.rationale: Perceived social role as a guide/leader reflects authority-based narcissism.

items.text: I know better than most people what's good for a group.
items.rationale: Belief in superior judgment about collective decisions is a hallmark of narcissistic authority.

items.text: I see myself as someone who is meant to be in charge.
items.rationale: Sense of destiny or inherent right to leadership maps directly to authority.

items.text: When I lead, things go better than when someone else is in charge.
items.rationale: Self-serving comparison of leadership outcomes reflects authority-based grandiosity.

items.text: I enjoy having authority over other people.
items.rationale: Direct endorsement of pleasure derived from hierarchical power.

items.text: Others would be wise to follow my advice more often.
items.rationale: Belief that one's counsel is undervalued reflects narcissistic authority and superiority.

items.text: I feel I have a special ability to lead people through difficult times.
items.rationale: Perceived unique leadership capacity in adversity maps to authority.

items.text: I'm the person everyone turns to when important decisions need to be made.
items.rationale: Perceived indispensability in decision-making reflects authority-based self-concept.

items.text: I have more leadership potential than most of the people I know.
items.rationale: Explicit social comparison on leadership ability is central to narcissistic authority.

items.text: I sometimes feel frustrated when others don't defer to my judgment.
items.rationale: Frustration at lack of deference maps to authority but could also reflect entitlement.

items.text: I think most groups would fall apart without a strong leader like me.
items.rationale: Captures authority but the grandiose self-importance could also map to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I deserve to be in a position of power because of my superior abilities.
items.rationale: The sense of deserving power maps to authority, but 'deserve' language also maps to Entitlement.

items.text: My self-worth depends heavily on how others evaluate me.
items.rationale: Directly captures the dependency of self-esteem on external validation.

items.text: When someone criticizes me, it shakes my confidence to the core.
items.rationale: Vulnerability to criticism reflects fragile, externally contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I feel good about myself only when I'm performing well or receiving praise.
items.rationale: Self-worth tied to performance and praise is the essence of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: A single failure can make me question my entire worth as a person.
items.rationale: Catastrophic impact of failure on self-concept reflects fragile narcissistic self-esteem.

items.text: I constantly compare myself to others to gauge how well I'm doing.
items.rationale: Social comparison as a self-evaluation strategy is central to contingent self-esteem.

items.text: My mood can shift dramatically depending on whether people approve of me.
items.rationale: Emotional reactivity to approval/disapproval reflects externally contingent self-worth.

items.text: I need reassurance from others to feel confident in my decisions.
items.rationale: Dependence on external reassurance for confidence maps to contingent self-esteem.

items.text: When I don't receive recognition for my efforts, I start to doubt myself.
items.rationale: Self-doubt triggered by lack of recognition reflects fragile, contingent self-worth.

items.text: I feel worthless when I'm not the best at something.
items.rationale: Self-worth contingent on being superior captures the competitive fragility of this facet.

items.text: My opinion of myself fluctuates a lot depending on my recent successes or failures.
items.rationale: Instability of self-evaluation tied to outcomes is a defining feature of contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I secretly worry that I'm not as competent as people think I am.
items.rationale: Impostor-like fears reflect the underlying fragility of narcissistic contingent self-esteem.

items.text: Being rejected or excluded makes me feel like there's something fundamentally wrong with me.
items.rationale: Rejection sensitivity tied to core self-worth reflects contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I sometimes feel like I'm only as good as my last achievement.
items.rationale: Achievement-contingent self-worth is central, though this could also relate to need for admiration.

items.text: I find it hard to feel secure about who I am unless others validate me.
items.rationale: Validation-seeking maps to contingent self-esteem but overlaps with need for admiration.

items.text: I crave positive feedback because without it I start to feel invisible and unimportant.
items.rationale: The craving for feedback maps to contingent self-esteem, but the desire to feel important overlaps with Need for Admiration.

items.text: Most people I meet are not worth my time or energy.
items.rationale: Dismissive evaluation of others' worth is the core of the devaluing facet.

items.text: I often think that the people around me are incompetent.
items.rationale: Chronic perception of others as incompetent reflects narcissistic devaluation.

items.text: I lose respect for people quickly once I see their flaws.
items.rationale: Rapid loss of respect upon discovering imperfections is characteristic of devaluing.

items.text: I find it hard to admire anyone because most people are mediocre.
items.rationale: Inability to admire others due to perceived mediocrity directly maps to devaluing.

items.text: When someone disappoints me, I tend to write them off completely.
items.rationale: All-or-nothing dismissal of others after disappointment reflects narcissistic devaluation.

items.text: I privately look down on people who aren't as smart or successful as I am.
items.rationale: Contempt based on perceived inferiority of others is central to devaluing.

items.text: I think most people are too weak to handle real challenges.
items.rationale: Viewing others as weak reflects a devaluing stance rooted in perceived superiority.

items.text: People who can't keep up with me intellectually bore me.
items.rationale: Dismissing others based on intellectual comparison reflects narcissistic devaluation.

items.text: I often feel surrounded by people who just don't measure up.
items.rationale: Chronic sense that others fall short of one's standards is a hallmark of devaluing.

items.text: I tend to see other people's achievements as less impressive than my own.
items.rationale: Minimizing others' accomplishments relative to one's own reflects devaluation.

items.text: I have little patience for people who can't figure things out on their own.
items.rationale: Impatience with perceived incompetence reflects contemptuous devaluation of others.

items.text: Most people are followers who lack original thought.
items.rationale: Blanket dismissal of others as unoriginal followers captures devaluing.

items.text: I sometimes feel contempt for people who seem overly emotional or needy.
items.rationale: Contempt for emotionality maps to devaluing but could also relate to hiding the self.

items.text: I notice other people's shortcomings much more than their strengths.
items.rationale: Attentional bias toward flaws maps to devaluing but could reflect general negativity.

items.text: I feel superior to most people, and I think that's justified given my abilities.
items.rationale: Feeling superior maps to devaluing others, but the self-aggrandizing justification also maps to Grandiose Fantasy.

items.text: I deserve special treatment because I'm different from ordinary people.
items.rationale: Explicit expectation of special treatment based on perceived uniqueness is core entitlement.

items.text: Rules that apply to other people shouldn't necessarily apply to me.
items.rationale: Belief in exemption from rules is a classic marker of narcissistic entitlement.

items.text: I get angry when I don't get the treatment I deserve.
items.rationale: Anger at perceived insufficient treatment directly reflects entitled expectations.

items.text: I expect people to go out of their way to accommodate my needs.
items.rationale: Expectation that others should prioritize one's needs is central to entitlement.

items.text: I shouldn't have to wait in line like everyone else.
items.rationale: Concrete behavioral example of expecting exemption from ordinary social norms.

items.text: If I want something, I feel I have a right to have it.
items.rationale: Equating desire with right reflects the core cognitive distortion of entitlement.

items.text: I feel insulted when I'm treated the same as everyone else.
items.rationale: Perceiving equal treatment as insulting reflects inflated expectations of special status.

items.text: I believe I am owed more than what I typically receive from others.
items.rationale: Chronic sense of being shortchanged reflects narcissistic entitlement.

items.text: People should recognize how special I am and treat me accordingly.
items.rationale: Demand for recognition-based differential treatment is a hallmark of entitlement.

items.text: I find it outrageous when I'm denied something I feel I've earned.
items.rationale: Outrage at denial of perceived entitlements reflects narcissistic entitlement.

items.text: I expect the best table at a restaurant, the best seat at a show—I deserve it.
items.rationale: Concrete expectation of preferential treatment in everyday situations maps to entitlement.

items.text: I don't think I should have to do menial tasks—those are beneath me.
items.rationale: Viewing ordinary tasks as beneath oneself reflects grandiose entitlement.

items.text: I sometimes feel resentful when others receive benefits that I don't.
items.rationale: Resentment at others' benefits maps to entitlement but could also reflect general envy.

items.text: I think my contributions are undervalued and I should be compensated more.
items.rationale: Feeling undervalued maps to entitlement but could also reflect contingent self-esteem.

items.text: I expect loyalty and devotion from the people close to me, even when I don't always reciprocate.
items.rationale: Expecting non-reciprocal loyalty maps to entitlement but the interpersonal exploitation aspect overlaps with Exploitativeness.

items.text: I love being the center of attention at social events.
items.rationale: Desire to be the focal point of social gatherings is the essence of exhibitionism.

items.text: I enjoy showing off my body, talents, or possessions to impress others.
items.rationale: Active display behavior aimed at impressing others directly maps to exhibitionism.

items.text: I dress in a way that ensures people notice me.
items.rationale: Strategic self-presentation through appearance to attract attention reflects exhibitionism.

items.text: I feel energized when all eyes are on me.
items.rationale: Positive arousal from being watched captures the affective component of exhibitionism.

items.text: I like to tell stories that showcase my accomplishments in dramatic fashion.
items.rationale: Dramatic self-promotion through storytelling is a behavioral marker of exhibitionism.

items.text: I go out of my way to make a memorable impression on people.
items.rationale: Effortful impression management aimed at being memorable reflects exhibitionism.

items.text: I enjoy performing or speaking in front of large audiences.
items.rationale: Pleasure from public performance and display maps to exhibitionism.

items.text: I tend to exaggerate my stories to make them more entertaining and to keep people's attention.
items.rationale: Exaggeration for attention and entertainment reflects exhibitionistic self-presentation.

items.text: I post frequently on social media because I want people to see what I'm doing.
items.rationale: Digital self-display for visibility is a modern behavioral expression of exhibitionism.

items.text: I feel deflated when I'm in a social situation and no one seems to notice me.
items.rationale: Negative affect from lack of attention reflects the motivational core of exhibitionism.

items.text: I have a flair for the dramatic and I enjoy using it.
items.rationale: Self-acknowledged dramatic style aimed at display maps to exhibitionism.

items.text: I like to make grand entrances and ensure people know I've arrived.
items.rationale: Deliberate attention-seeking through dramatic arrivals is a classic exhibitionistic behavior.

items.text: I sometimes do outrageous things just to get a reaction from people.
items.rationale: Provocative behavior for reactions maps to exhibitionism but could also reflect impulsivity or antisocial traits.

items.text: I feel most alive when people are watching me and reacting to what I do.
items.rationale: Vitality from being observed maps to exhibitionism but could overlap with need for admiration.

items.text: I want people to admire me when I walk into a room.
items.rationale: Wanting admiration upon entry is exhibitionistic, but the admiration-seeking component overlaps with Need for Admiration.

items.text: I have no problem using people to get what I want.
items.rationale: Willingness to instrumentalize others is the defining feature of exploitativeness.

items.text: I can easily manipulate people into doing things for me.
items.rationale: Self-acknowledged manipulative ability directly maps to exploitativeness.

items.text: I often figure out what someone wants and use that knowledge to my advantage.
items.rationale: Strategic use of others' desires for personal gain is a core exploitative behavior.

items.text: I see relationships primarily in terms of what others can do for me.
items.rationale: Instrumental view of relationships is central to narcissistic exploitativeness.

items.text: I'm good at getting people to do favors for me, even when they don't really want to.
items.rationale: Ability to extract unwilling compliance from others reflects exploitative skill.

items.text: I don't feel guilty about taking advantage of someone if it benefits me.
items.rationale: Lack of guilt about exploitation captures both the behavior and the affective indifference of this facet.

items.text: I've used flattery strategically to get what I need from someone.
items.rationale: Strategic flattery as a manipulation tool is a specific exploitative tactic.

items.text: If someone is naive enough to be taken advantage of, that's their problem.
items.rationale: Victim-blaming rationalization of exploitation is characteristic of this facet.

items.text: I know how to charm people into giving me what I want.
items.rationale: Charm used instrumentally for personal gain maps to exploitativeness.

items.text: I tend to befriend people who can be useful to me in some way.
items.rationale: Utilitarian friendship selection reflects the instrumental orientation of exploitativeness.

items.text: I've pretended to care about someone's problems just to get something from them later.
items.rationale: Feigning empathy for instrumental purposes is a clear exploitative behavior.

items.text: I'm willing to step on others to get ahead if that's what it takes.
items.rationale: Willingness to harm others for personal advancement is a hallmark of exploitativeness.

items.text: I sometimes tell people what they want to hear so they'll like me and do things for me.
items.rationale: People-pleasing for instrumental gain maps to exploitativeness but could also reflect hiding the self.

items.text: I find it easy to read people and figure out how to influence them.
items.rationale: Social perceptiveness for influence maps to exploitativeness but could also reflect general social intelligence.

items.text: I use my social skills to get people to do what I want, and I think that's just smart leadership.
items.rationale: Using social influence instrumentally maps to exploitativeness, but framing it as leadership overlaps with Authority.

items.text: I often daydream about achieving something truly extraordinary that would change the world.
items.rationale: Fantasies of world-changing achievement are the essence of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I imagine myself becoming incredibly famous and admired by millions.
items.rationale: Fantasies of fame and mass admiration directly map to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I believe I'm destined for greatness, even if others can't see it yet.
items.rationale: Sense of unrecognized destiny reflects the future-oriented grandiosity of this facet.

items.text: I spend a lot of time thinking about the power and success I will one day have.
items.rationale: Preoccupation with future power and success is central to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: In my mind, I've already accomplished things that most people can only dream of.
items.rationale: Mental rehearsal of extraordinary accomplishments captures grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I sometimes picture myself receiving a major award or honor in front of a huge audience.
items.rationale: Specific fantasies of public recognition and honor map to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I fantasize about having unlimited wealth and the lifestyle that comes with it.
items.rationale: Fantasies of unlimited wealth and luxury are a common expression of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I think about how history will remember me as someone truly exceptional.
items.rationale: Preoccupation with historical legacy reflects the scope of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I often imagine scenarios where I single-handedly save the day.
items.rationale: Hero fantasies where one is the sole savior are classic grandiose fantasies.

items.text: I believe I have a unique gift that will eventually be recognized by the world.
items.rationale: Belief in a unique, world-recognized gift captures the core of grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I daydream about being so powerful that no one could ever challenge me.
items.rationale: Fantasies of unchallengeable power reflect grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I envision a future where I'm at the very top of my field, far above everyone else.
items.rationale: Fantasies of being at the pinnacle with clear superiority map to grandiose fantasy.

items.text: I sometimes get lost in thoughts about how much better my life will be once people realize how talented I am.
items.rationale: Future-oriented fantasy about recognition maps to grandiose fantasy but the recognition-seeking element could overlap with need for admiration.

items.text: I think I have the potential to be one of the most important people alive.
items.rationale: Belief in extraordinary potential maps to grandiose fantasy but could also reflect authority-based self-concept.

items.text: I know I'm meant for something bigger than what I'm currently doing, and I think about it constantly.
items.rationale: Sense of being destined for more maps to grandiose fantasy, but the dissatisfaction with current status could also reflect Contingent Self-Esteem.

items.text: I rarely let people see the real me.
items.rationale: Deliberate concealment of one's authentic self is the core of hiding the self.

items.text: I keep my true feelings hidden because showing vulnerability would be a weakness.
items.rationale: Concealing emotions to avoid appearing weak directly maps to hiding the self.

items.text: I present a carefully crafted image to the world that doesn't reflect who I really am inside.
items.rationale: Maintaining a false public persona is central to hiding the self.

items.text: I'm afraid that if people knew the real me, they would think less of me.
items.rationale: Fear of devaluation upon self-disclosure reflects the protective motivation of hiding the self.

items.text: I avoid deep conversations because they might reveal things about me I'd rather keep private.
items.rationale: Avoidance of intimacy to prevent self-exposure maps to hiding the self.

items.text: I wear a mask in social situations—people see what I want them to see.
items.rationale: Metaphor of wearing a mask captures the deliberate self-concealment of this facet.

items.text: I would never admit my insecurities to anyone.
items.rationale: Refusal to disclose insecurities reflects the protective concealment of hiding the self.

items.text: I go to great lengths to make sure no one sees my weaknesses.
items.rationale: Active effort to conceal weaknesses is a behavioral hallmark of hiding the self.

items.text: Even my closest friends don't really know what I'm thinking or feeling most of the time.
items.rationale: Emotional opacity even in close relationships reflects pervasive self-concealment.

items.text: I feel like there's a gap between who I appear to be and who I actually am.
items.rationale: Awareness of discrepancy between public and private self is central to hiding the self.

items.text: Showing my emotions feels dangerous, like giving someone ammunition to use against me.
items.rationale: Viewing emotional expression as a strategic vulnerability reflects the defensive nature of hiding the self.

items.text: I carefully control what information about myself I share with others.
items.rationale: Strategic information management about oneself maps to hiding the self.

items.text: I sometimes feel exhausted from maintaining the image I project to others.
items.rationale: Fatigue from impression management maps to hiding the self but could also relate to exhibitionism's performative demands.

items.text: I worry that people would reject me if they saw my flaws.
items.rationale: Fear of rejection upon exposure maps to hiding the self but overlaps with contingent self-esteem's rejection sensitivity.

items.text: I put on a confident front even when I'm falling apart inside, because I need people to see me as strong.
items.rationale: Concealing vulnerability maps to hiding the self, but the need for others to see strength overlaps with Need for Admiration.

items.text: I need people to tell me how great I am in order to feel good about myself.
items.rationale: Explicit dependence on external praise for self-worth is the core of need for admiration.

items.text: I feel empty inside when no one is paying attention to me or praising me.
items.rationale: Emotional emptiness without admiration reflects the affective dependency of this facet.

items.text: I go out of my way to do things that will earn me compliments and recognition.
items.rationale: Effortful behavior aimed at eliciting admiration directly maps to this facet.

items.text: I feel a strong need to be recognized for my talents and accomplishments.
items.rationale: Explicit need for recognition of abilities is central to need for admiration.

items.text: It bothers me deeply when my achievements go unnoticed.
items.rationale: Distress at lack of recognition for achievements reflects need for admiration.

items.text: I fish for compliments more often than I'd like to admit.
items.rationale: Compliment-seeking behavior is a direct behavioral expression of need for admiration.

items.text: I check how many likes and comments I get on social media because it makes me feel valued.
items.rationale: Using social media metrics as a source of validation reflects modern need for admiration.

items.text: I feel happiest when someone expresses genuine admiration for who I am.
items.rationale: Peak positive affect tied to receiving admiration maps to this facet.

items.text: I often steer conversations toward topics where I know I'll be praised.
items.rationale: Strategic conversation management to elicit praise reflects need for admiration.

items.text: I feel unsettled if I go too long without someone acknowledging my worth.
items.rationale: Discomfort from prolonged absence of acknowledgment reflects admiration dependency.

items.text: I thrive on compliments—they fuel my motivation and sense of self.
items.rationale: Compliments as fuel for motivation and identity reflects the functional role of admiration.

items.text: I want people to look up to me and see me as someone special.
items.rationale: Desire to be viewed as special and admired maps directly to need for admiration.

items.text: I sometimes feel jealous when someone else gets the praise I think I deserve.
items.rationale: Jealousy over others' praise maps to need for admiration but could also reflect entitlement.

items.text: I work hard partly because I want people to be impressed by what I accomplish.
items.rationale: Admiration as a work motivator maps to this facet but could also reflect general achievement motivation.

items.text: I feel most confident when I know that others are impressed by me, and I feel lost without that feedback.
items.rationale: Confidence contingent on others' impressions maps to need for admiration, but the loss of confidence without feedback overlaps with Contingent Self-Esteem.

items.text: I rarely second-guess my decisions because I know my judgment is superior.
items.rationale: Directly reflects inflated self-assessment of one's own judgment, a core feature of narcissistic overconfidence.

items.text: When I walk into a room, I assume I'm the most capable person there.
items.rationale: Grandiose self-appraisal of competence relative to others is central to overconfidence.

items.text: I trust my instincts more than the advice of so-called experts.
items.rationale: Dismissing expert opinion in favor of one's own intuition reflects inflated self-certainty.

items.text: People who know me would say I never doubt myself, even when I probably should.
items.rationale: Third-person observation style capturing the absence of self-doubt characteristic of overconfidence.

items.text: I could succeed at almost anything I put my mind to, even without much preparation.
items.rationale: Belief in effortless success reflects grandiose overestimation of one's abilities.

items.text: I've been told I overestimate my abilities, but I think others just underestimate me.
items.rationale: Reframing feedback about overestimation as others' failure to recognize one's talent is classic overconfidence.

items.text: If I were in charge, most problems would be solved much faster.
items.rationale: Grandiose belief in one's leadership and problem-solving superiority.

items.text: I don't need to study as hard as other people because things come naturally to me.
items.rationale: Belief in innate superiority that exempts one from ordinary effort.

items.text: My track record speaks for itself — I'm right far more often than most people.
items.rationale: Self-serving appraisal of one's accuracy and correctness relative to others.

items.text: I feel completely certain about my opinions even on topics I haven't studied deeply.
items.rationale: Certainty without adequate knowledge base is a hallmark of narcissistic overconfidence.

items.text: When things go wrong, it's almost never because of a mistake I made.
items.rationale: Externalizing blame while maintaining inflated self-assessment of competence.

items.text: I have a natural talent that sets me apart from the average person.
items.rationale: Belief in exceptional, innate talent reflects grandiose self-appraisal.

items.text: Sometimes I take on challenges that are probably beyond my skill level, but I genuinely believe I'll figure it out.
items.rationale: Could reflect healthy self-efficacy or growth mindset, but the pattern of overcommitting due to inflated self-belief leans toward overconfidence.

items.text: I tend to assume I'll outperform my peers in competitive situations.
items.rationale: Competitive self-assurance could reflect genuine competence or narcissistic inflation; context-dependent.

items.text: I don't need validation from others because I already know how good I am.
items.rationale: While reflecting inflated self-assessment, the independence from external validation also maps onto Self-Sufficiency.

items.text: I can go from calm to furious in seconds if someone disrespects me.
items.rationale: Rapid escalation to fury in response to perceived disrespect is the core of narcissistic reactive anger.

items.text: When someone criticizes me, my first instinct is to lash out.
items.rationale: Aggressive response to criticism reflects ego-threat-driven anger characteristic of this factor.

items.text: People have told me I overreact when I feel slighted.
items.rationale: Third-person feedback about disproportionate anger responses to perceived slights.

items.text: I've said things in anger that I later regretted, but in the moment it felt completely justified.
items.rationale: Impulsive verbal aggression with in-the-moment justification reflects narcissistic rage dynamics.

items.text: If someone embarrasses me in front of others, I feel an overwhelming urge to retaliate.
items.rationale: Public humiliation triggering retaliatory urges is a classic narcissistic anger response.

items.text: I hold grudges against people who have wronged me and find it hard to let go.
items.rationale: Persistent resentment following perceived wrongs reflects the sustained quality of narcissistic anger.

items.text: When I feel disrespected, I want the other person to know exactly how angry I am.
items.rationale: Need to communicate anger intensity in response to disrespect reflects reactive anger expression.

items.text: I become hostile when people question my competence or authority.
items.rationale: Hostility triggered by challenges to competence or status reflects ego-threat-driven anger.

items.text: My anger can be explosive, and people around me have learned to walk on eggshells.
items.rationale: Explosive anger creating an intimidating interpersonal environment is a behavioral marker of reactive anger.

items.text: I've gotten into arguments because I felt someone was trying to make me look foolish.
items.rationale: Conflict initiated by perceived attempts to undermine one's image reflects narcissistic anger.

items.text: Even minor slights can ruin my entire day because I keep replaying them in my mind.
items.rationale: Rumination over minor perceived slights with disproportionate emotional impact reflects reactive anger.

items.text: I find it almost impossible to stay calm when someone talks down to me.
items.rationale: Inability to regulate anger when feeling condescended to is a direct expression of reactive anger.

items.text: Sometimes I snap at people and then feel confused about why I reacted so strongly.
items.rationale: The confusion about one's own reaction could suggest lower self-awareness, but the snapping behavior maps to reactive anger. Some overlap with general emotional dysregulation.

items.text: I get frustrated easily when people don't meet my expectations.
items.rationale: Frustration with unmet expectations could reflect general low agreeableness or entitlement, but the anger component maps primarily to reactive anger.

items.text: When someone insults me, I feel both enraged and deeply wounded at the same time.
items.rationale: The rage component maps to Reactive Anger, but the deep wounding suggests vulnerability and could map to Shame or Insecurity.

items.text: I spend a lot of time thinking about my own goals, needs, and desires.
items.rationale: Excessive preoccupation with one's own internal world and needs is the defining feature of self-absorption.

items.text: In conversations, I tend to steer the topic back to myself without realizing it.
items.rationale: Unconscious conversational self-focus is a behavioral hallmark of narcissistic self-absorption.

items.text: I often feel like my problems are more important or complex than other people's.
items.rationale: Elevating one's own concerns above others' reflects the self-centered perspective of self-absorption.

items.text: I check my appearance multiple times a day and think a lot about how I come across.
items.rationale: Excessive self-monitoring of appearance and impression reflects narcissistic preoccupation with self-image.

items.text: When something happens to someone else, I often find myself thinking about how it affects me.
items.rationale: Recentering others' experiences around oneself is a core cognitive pattern of self-absorption.

items.text: I enjoy talking about my achievements and experiences more than listening to others talk about theirs.
items.rationale: Preference for self-focused discourse over reciprocal listening reflects narcissistic self-preoccupation.

items.text: Friends have pointed out that I don't ask about their lives as much as I talk about mine.
items.rationale: Third-person feedback about conversational imbalance directly captures self-absorption in relationships.

items.text: I daydream frequently about my future success and the life I deserve.
items.rationale: Grandiose fantasy and entitlement-laden daydreaming reflect narcissistic self-preoccupation.

items.text: I find it difficult to be genuinely happy for other people's accomplishments.
items.rationale: Inability to celebrate others' success due to self-referential processing is characteristic of self-absorption.

items.text: I tend to interpret most situations in terms of what they mean for me personally.
items.rationale: Self-referential interpretation of events is a cognitive hallmark of narcissistic self-absorption.

items.text: I spend more time thinking about my own feelings than trying to understand how others feel.
items.rationale: Prioritizing self-focused emotional processing over empathic engagement reflects self-absorption.

items.text: I feel most alive when the attention is on me.
items.rationale: Deriving vitality from being the center of attention reflects narcissistic self-preoccupation.

items.text: I sometimes zone out when others are talking because I'm preoccupied with my own thoughts.
items.rationale: Could reflect general inattentiveness or ADHD-like traits, but in the narcissism context it maps to self-preoccupation.

items.text: I put a lot of effort into curating how I present myself on social media.
items.rationale: Social media self-curation is common and could reflect normal self-presentation, but excessive focus maps to self-absorption.

items.text: I need people to acknowledge my accomplishments or I feel like they don't matter.
items.rationale: While the focus on one's own accomplishments reflects self-absorption, the need for external validation and the conditional self-worth could map to Shame or Insecurity.

items.text: I prefer to handle my problems on my own rather than rely on anyone else.
items.rationale: Strong preference for independent problem-solving and avoidance of reliance on others is central to narcissistic self-sufficiency.

items.text: Asking for help feels like admitting weakness, so I almost never do it.
items.rationale: Equating help-seeking with weakness reflects the defensive autonomy characteristic of narcissistic self-sufficiency.

items.text: I don't like being in anyone's debt — emotional or otherwise.
items.rationale: Aversion to interpersonal indebtedness reflects the need to maintain an autonomous, superior position.

items.text: I've always been the kind of person who figures things out alone.
items.rationale: Lifelong pattern of solitary problem-solving reflects trait-level narcissistic self-sufficiency.

items.text: I feel uncomfortable when I have to depend on someone else for something important.
items.rationale: Discomfort with dependency reflects the narcissistic need to maintain control and autonomy.

items.text: Other people would slow me down — I work best when I'm in complete control.
items.rationale: Viewing others as impediments and preferring total control reflects grandiose self-sufficiency.

items.text: I take pride in never needing anyone to take care of me.
items.rationale: Pride in independence from caregiving reflects the identity-level investment in self-sufficiency.

items.text: Even when I'm struggling, I put on a strong front because I don't want people to see me as vulnerable.
items.rationale: Concealing vulnerability to maintain an image of strength reflects defensive self-sufficiency.

items.text: I believe that if you want something done right, you have to do it yourself.
items.rationale: Distrust of others' competence driving self-reliance is a common expression of narcissistic self-sufficiency.

items.text: I'd rather fail on my own terms than succeed because someone helped me.
items.rationale: Valuing autonomous failure over assisted success reflects extreme investment in self-sufficiency.

items.text: Emotional closeness makes me uncomfortable because it means someone could have power over me.
items.rationale: Framing intimacy as a power vulnerability reflects the defensive autonomy of narcissistic self-sufficiency.

items.text: I don't share my personal struggles with anyone — that's my business alone.
items.rationale: Strict emotional privacy and refusal to disclose struggles reflects narcissistic self-containment.

items.text: I'm resourceful and can usually find a way to get what I need without asking.
items.rationale: Resourcefulness could reflect healthy independence or adaptive coping, but the emphasis on avoiding asking maps to self-sufficiency.

items.text: I tend to keep people at arm's length because I've learned I can only count on myself.
items.rationale: Could reflect attachment avoidance or interpersonal distrust more broadly, but the self-reliance emphasis maps to self-sufficiency.

items.text: I don't need other people's opinions to feel confident in my choices.
items.rationale: Independence from others' opinions maps to self-sufficiency, but the confidence in one's own judgment also maps to Overconfidence.

items.text: Deep down, I worry that I'm not as talented as people think I am.
items.rationale: Covert fear of being exposed as less capable than one's public image reflects core narcissistic shame.

items.text: I feel a wave of shame when I make even a small mistake in front of others.
items.rationale: Disproportionate shame response to minor public errors is a hallmark of vulnerable narcissistic insecurity.

items.text: I constantly compare myself to others and usually feel like I come up short.
items.rationale: Chronic social comparison with negative self-evaluation reflects narcissistic insecurity.

items.text: Criticism stings me far more than I let on — it can haunt me for days.
items.rationale: Concealed hypersensitivity to criticism with prolonged rumination reflects vulnerable narcissistic shame.

items.text: I sometimes feel like a fraud who will eventually be found out.
items.rationale: Impostor-like feelings reflect the fragile self-esteem and fear of exposure central to narcissistic shame.

items.text: When I'm not praised or recognized, I start to doubt my own worth.
items.rationale: Contingent self-worth dependent on external validation reflects narcissistic insecurity.

items.text: I replay embarrassing moments over and over in my head, sometimes for years.
items.rationale: Chronic shame-based rumination over past embarrassments is characteristic of vulnerable narcissism.

items.text: I put on a confident exterior, but inside I'm often filled with self-doubt.
items.rationale: Discrepancy between public confidence and private self-doubt captures the core of narcissistic shame.

items.text: I feel deeply humiliated when someone points out a flaw of mine, especially publicly.
items.rationale: Intense humiliation in response to public exposure of flaws reflects narcissistic shame sensitivity.

items.text: I need constant reassurance that I'm doing well, or I start to spiral into self-criticism.
items.rationale: Dependence on external reassurance to prevent self-critical spirals reflects fragile narcissistic self-esteem.

items.text: I'm terrified of being seen as ordinary or mediocre.
items.rationale: Fear of being perceived as average reflects the narcissistic need for specialness driven by underlying insecurity.

items.text: When I fail at something, I feel not just disappointed but fundamentally defective.
items.rationale: Globalizing failure into a sense of core defectiveness reflects shame-based narcissistic processing.

items.text: I sometimes feel envious of others and then ashamed of feeling that way.
items.rationale: Envy with secondary shame captures narcissistic insecurity, though envy alone could map to self-absorption or general narcissism.

items.text: I avoid situations where I might not excel because the possibility of failure feels unbearable.
items.rationale: Performance avoidance driven by intolerance of failure maps to shame, though it could also reflect perfectionism or anxiety more broadly.

items.text: When someone doesn't give me the recognition I expected, I feel both hurt and furious.
items.rationale: The hurt and wounded self-esteem map to Shame or Insecurity, but the fury component could map to Reactive Anger.
